etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Thomas Thomson. From anemone + -in, after either German Anemonin or French anémonine (both 1817 or earlier)

definitions: An acrid crystalline substance which occurs in various plants of the genera Anemone and Ranunculus (family Ranunculaceae) and is a dimer of the toxic compound protoanemonin.

notes.text: Anemonin is a tricyclic unsaturated lactone, C₁₀H₈O₄.
